FX option implied volatility and USD call premiums have exploded higher this
week as FX volatility risk roars back. Liquidity issues are likely to have
exacerbated the moves as traders struggled to unwind short positions.
    EUR/USD is probably the most liquid currency pair but still saw some extreme
gains. Benchmark 1-month expiry implied volatility peaked at 7.15 from a recent
and multi-year low at 4.9 and 1-year expiry rose to 7.2 from its own long-term
low of 6.1. Risk reversals increased their USD call versus put implied vol
premiums to 13-month highs, with 1-month 0.25 to 0.8, 3-month 0.4 to 0.95 and
1-year 0.7 to 1.2 over recent sessions. 
    Implied vol gains have since peaked because FX realised volatility remains
subdued and liquidity is slowly returning, with some big impending expiries
playing their part. However, diverging policy outlooks and simmering
geopolitical risks should limit setbacks. There is talk of further EUR/USD
losses and even parity, the odds of which appear low when looking at binary
option prices. 
    The situation is similar in other major currency pairs, except for the JPY,
where a big implied volatility premium for JPY calls dominates amid the threat
of official intervention.

Nov 6 (Reuters) - U.S. voters cast ballots in a tight contest and early
projections will appear in Asia, suggesting a potentially choppy session on
Wednesday. Wall Street closed higher, the Treasury curve flattened, commodities
firmed and the safe-haven U.S. dollar fell with investors upbeat into Tuesday's
election.
    A positive lead for Asian markets with EM ETFs up 1.3%. Thailand and Taiwan
inflation, and India services PMI lead the busy regional data schedule, with a
rate decision in Malaysia. Early projections for the U.S. election will dominate
the wires and lead the FX markets, while regional markets will concentrate on
data.
     Bank Negara Malaysia is expected to keep the overnight policy rate
unchanged at 3.00%, and to hold it there at least through 2025, as economists
expect growth to remain strong and inflation steady.
    Dow +1.02%, S&P +1.22%, and Nasdaq +1.43%, as strong ISM Services PMI helped
fuel optimism. The Treasury curve flattened into the election aided by a
well-received 10-year auction; 2yr +2bps to 4.193%, 10yr -3bps to 4.277%, 30yr
-5bps to 4.44% on TradeWeb. The CME FedWatch Tool prices a 25-basis-point
Federal Reserve rate cut on Nov 7 at 99%.  
    Commodities firmed, Brent oil +0.8%, WTI +1%, as a storm threatens
production in the Gulf of Mexico. U.S. copper +0.7%, supported by the softer USD

About Bank Of Beijing

The Bank of Beijing Co., Ltd. is a commercial bank operating in China's capital city, Beijing. The company offers a wide range of financial services, including deposits, loans, settlement, bill discounting, government bond underwriting, trade finance, investment banking, wealth management, asset custody, and fund services. Their target client base includes enterprises and individuals. You can find more information about their offerings on their website, www.bankofbeijing.com.cn, and they are listed on the Shanghai Stock Exchange. Their Initial Public Offering (IPO) took place on September 19, 2007.

(Updates as of 1623 ET)
    By Alden Bentley, Amanda Cooper and Kevin Buckland
       NEW YORK/LONDON/TOKYO, March 27 (Reuters) - Global share
markets advanced cautiously on Wednesday, led by an early rally
in Japanese stocks as the yen sagged to its weakest since 1990,
prompting intervention fears, while benchmark U.S. Treasury
yields fell after a strong seven-year note auction.   
    Trading was subdued with the dollar stuck in a narrow range
below its overnight high against the yen as markets marked time
ahead of Friday's much-anticipated U.S. inflation report, that
few will be around to digest at the start of the long Easter
weekend in the United States and many other countries.
    The yen, which has lost more than 7% in value against the
dollar this year already, weakened as far as 151.975 to the
dollar, prompting Japan's three main monetary authorities to
hold an emergency meeting on Wednesday to discuss the currency.
    Market participants took this as a signal officials were
ready to intervene in the market to stop what they described as
disorderly and speculative moves in the yen, a carry-trade
favorite for speculators to short against other currencies
because of its lower interest rates.
    "The news this morning was the Japanese yen. They're always
concerned, even well before this for so many years, about hedge
funds coming in and taking advantage of the yen," said Quincy
Krosby, chief global strategist at LPL Financial, in Charlotte,
NC. "So they typically come out with the warning to notify the
market that 'we could come in and thwart your ambition in our
currency market'."
    The yen has been sliding despite the Bank of Japan's first
interest rate hike for 17 years last week, as traders expect
very gradual tightening and possible delays to long-expected
Federal Reserve easing.
    BOJ board member Naoki Tamura reinforced the dovish outlook
on further tightening on Wednesday, saying the central bank
should "move slowly but steadily toward policy normalisation".
    The stocks rally ramped up late in Wall Street's session.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average <.DJI> rose  1.22%, to end at
39,760.08, outpacing the other main indexes because of a strong
rally in Merck <MRK.N> after the U.S. Food and Drug
Administration approved its therapy for adults suffering from a
rare lung condition. 
    The S&P 500 <.SPX> gained 0.86%, closing at 5,248.49 and the
Nasdaq Composite <.IXIC> gained 0.51% to 16,399.52. 
    The Nikkei <.N225> closed 0.9% higher. MSCI's gauge of
stocks across the globe <.MIWD00000PUS> rose 0.59%, while
Europe's STOXX 600 <.STOXX> index added 0.13%.
    "It's choppy, directionless trading, and there's a good
reason for that: we've hit that time of the quarter when
rebalancing flows are impacting the market," said Tony Sycamore,
a strategist at IG.
    Another reason is that two key events - the release of the
U.S. Federal Reserve's favoured Personal Consumption
Expenditures Inflation Index and public comments from Fed Chair
Jerome Powell - come on Friday, when most markets are closed for
a holiday, he added. 
    Good Friday is a market but not a government holiday in the
United States.
    
    DOLLAR/YEN IN FOCUS
    Against the yen <JPY=>, the dollar eased 0.15% to 151.32.
The dollar index <=USD> was down 0.14% at 104.28, just below
Friday's five-week high of 104.49, while the euro <EUR=> was
down 0.04% at $1.0826.
    "If there's any kind of intervention, it only has a
significant lasting impact if the direction of travel has
already begun to turn," Guy Miller, chief market strategist at
Zurich Insurance Group, said.
    U.S. 10-year Treasury yields <US10YT=RR> were 4.6 basis
points lower at 4.188%. They had fallen as far as 4.182%, the
lowest in two weeks, after the Treasury easily sold $43 billion
of seven-year notes amid expectations that the Federal Reserve
will be lowering rates soon. 
    Kim Rupert, managing director of global fixed income at
Action Economics in San Francisco, described the auction as
"stellar." 
    "It's a good time to pick up some yield," she said.
    Traders are trying to gauge which of the big central banks -
the Fed, ECB or Bank of England - will be first to cut rates
this year.
    Meanwhile, Sweden's Riksbank left interest rates unchanged
but indicated it was likely to start easing monetary policy in
either May or June.
    Spot gold <XAU=> rose 0.73% to $2,194.43 an ounce as it
continued to search for a short-term floor following its surge
to a record $2,222.39 last week. U.S. gold futures <GCc1> rose
0.67% to $2,191.70 an ounce.
    Cryptocurrency bitcoin <BTC=> fell 1.11% to $69,038.01. 
    Oil fell for a second day after a report that crude
stockpiles surged in the U.S., the world's biggest oil user, and
on signs major producers are unlikely to change their output
policy at a technical meeting next week. [O/R]
    Brent <LCOc1> crude futures settled at $86.09 per barrel,
down 0.19%. U.S. crude futures <CLc1> settled down 0.33% at
$81.35 a barrel.

LCH sees new members and products sustaining FX options growthSpeaking to FOW, LCH' s new head of ForexClear Andrew Batchelor reflected on the firm's recent spike in FX options activity, with average daily volume up 81% last month to $16 billion. Volume for the first three weeks of June is running at what would be a monthly record of $21 billion, compared to $10 billion in June 2023, while June 27 marked a record $48 billion of FX... The new head of LCH's foreign exchange clearing service has said the involvement of more banks and buy-side firms coupled with new currency pairs should accelerate the recent growth in ForexClear's options markets.

Speaking to FOW, LCH's new head of ForexClear Andrew Batchelor reflected on the firm's recent spike in FX options activity, with average daily volume up 81% last month to $16 billion (?12.6bn).

Volume for the first three weeks of June is running at what would be a monthly record of $21 billion, compared to $10 billion in June 2023, while June 27 marked a record $48 billion of FX options notional cleared on a single day.

"The overall 100% year-on-year growth in ADV demonstrates the strong demand for clearing, and with the thirteenth large bank joining in June, we expect this upward trend to continue," Batchelor said in an interview. "We believe there is considerable upside from here as we go through the work of extending tenors, adding currency pairs and enhancing connectivity with the other banks.

"As we expand the offering to include USD/CAD or USD/CNH FX Options, which is planned for the end of 2025, those regional and international banks that have exposures will be very attracted by the benefits of clearing."

Overall, ForexClear cleared $2.9 trillion of contracts in May, a 45% year-on-year increase as non-deliverable forwards (NDFs), client clearing and options have all seen gains on last year partly due to regulatory capital charges on bank's over-the-counter derivatives books, said Batchelor, who was this month promoted to head of ForexClear from his former role of chief operating officer.

"Our biggest bank members have been quite deliberate and robust in deploying their clearing strategies, and you can see that in the volume growth across ForexClear," he added. "Even in NDFs, which is a relatively mature market for us, our ADV was up 40% year-on-year in May, to $130 billion. We are one of the largest NDF counterparties in the market, and that is driven primarily by bank flows as they clear more of their book.

"Two large banks have recently joined as members in June 2024 and we are seeing more buy-side clients joining as well. As the volumes grow, the portfolio effect generates benefits from clearing other products such as FX Options and FX Forwards." LCH ForexClear did not disclose the names of the banks.

There are currently 84 clients and 41 member entities live on LCH ForexClear, with seven new clients joining this year, according to figures provided by the firm. ForexClear in November 2023 launched its "smart clearing" service in partnership with LSEG-owned Quantile to enable optimised clearing and compression of FX forwards.

"FX Smart Clearing has been additive to that," Batchelor said. "If you have a big pool of risk in the clearing house and are benefiting from netting and cross margining, there are material capital benefits which can be generated from clearing FX Forwards, without increasing initial margin. The two things work hand-in-hand.

"We have six banks that are live on Smart Clearing and expect to add more later this year. In the coming months, the technological and operational processes will be further enhanced and will further attract additional participants."

Buy-side firms are switching to listed and cleared derivatives from bank-dominated over-the-counter (OTC) products, generating interest in the smaller listed FX options market, an executive at Eurex said in May.

CME Group said last month futures markets have become a "meaningful" tool for price discovery, as the US exchange prepares to roll-out a new pricing functionality for spot markets derived from its listed venues.

    By Summer Zhen
       HONG KONG, April 17 (Reuters) - China's yuan traded
lower against dollar on Wednesday after comments by U.S. Federal
Reserve Chair Jerome Powell indicated that interest rates could
stay higher for longer. 
    The yuan <CNY=CFXS> was trading at 7.2396 per dollar at 0309
 GMT, down a touch from the previous close. The central bank's
daily benchmark fixings and support from state-owned banks have
slowed its decline. 
    The currency hit a five-month low of 7.2422 on Tuesday, and
is down roughly 2% this year, pressured by its relative low
yields versus other currencies and outflows of foreign
investment from an anaemic stock market. 
    Top U.S. central bank officials including Powell backed away
on Tuesday from providing any guidance on when interest rates
may be cut, saying instead that monetary policy needs to be
restrictive for longer. That further dashed investor hopes for
significant easing this year and put pressure on Asian
currencies. 
    The People's Bank of China set the midpoint rate <CNY=PBOC>,
around which the yuan is allowed to trade in a 2% band, at
7.1025 per U.S. dollar prior to market open, firmer than the
previous fix 7.1028. 
    An elevated strengthening bias implied by the daily fixing
rate points to a desire to limit the pace of currency
depreciation from the PBOC, Goldman Sachs analysts said in a
note, adding that USD/CNY remains "in a tug-of-war between
depreciation pressures and policy controls". 
    China reported better-than-expected economic growth in the
first quarter on Tuesday. 
    The improving economic conditions leaves room for the
central bank to keep its policy rate on hold in the near term,
DBS analysts said in a note.
    In the spot market, the spot yuan <CNY=CFXS> opened at
7.2360 per dollar and was changing hands at 7.2396 at midday.
The offshore yuan <CNH=D3> was trading -0.29% away from the
onshore spot at 7.2603 per dollar. 
    The global dollar index <=USD> fell to 106.242 from the
previous close of 106.257.

Oct 15 (Reuters) - 
    The U.S. Treasury market was closed for Columbus Day, but other markets
functioned on Monday. The U.S. dollar and Wall Street climbed with the S&P and
Dow at record levels, while commodities fell.
    A positive lead for Asian markets, though EM ETFs eased 0.4%. Trade figures
in South Korea and Indonesia lead the low-key regional data schedule. The focus
in Asia will be on Japan's return from the long weekend, and sentiment in China
markets, awaiting details of upcoming economic support measures. 
    Chinese trade figures missed forecasts on Monday, as did loan data,
supporting the view that further stimulus is required. Caixin Global was told
China may raise an additional 6 trillion yuan from treasury bonds over three
years to support the slowing economy through fiscal stimulus. 
    Dow +0.47%, S&P +0.77%, and Nasdaq +0.87%, led by Nvidia in light trading on
optimism towards the upcoming corporate earnings season.
    Oil fell as OPEC cut its outlook for global demand, Brent -3.75%, WTI
-4.25%. U.S. copper -2.15% on the lack of China stimulus details; and gold
-0.3%, capped by the stronger USD.
    The U.S. dollar <=USD> climbed 0.3%, up 2.4% in October supported by
resilient data, expectations of only a quarter-point Federal Reserve rate cut,
and hopes of a 'soft landing' for the U.S. economy. EUR -0.25%, GBP -0.05%,
USD/JPY +0.45%, USD/CNH +0.35%, AUD -0.4%, NZD -0.3% and USD/CAD +0.25%.

Nov 27 (Reuters) - Federal Reserve officials adopted a cautious stance
on rate cuts in the minutes for the November meeting. President Joe Biden said
an Israel-Hezbollah ceasefire will take effect Wednesday morning.
    Wall Street and Treasury yields closed higher, the U.S. dollar was little
changed, but the yen strengthened on rate hike hopes, and commodities closed
mixed on Tuesday.
    A positive lead for Asian markets, though EM ETFs closed down 0.4%.
Australian inflation, the key to Reserve Bank of Australia monetary policy,
Chinese industrial profits, and Thai manufacturing lead the regional data
schedule, while New Zealand has a rate decision. Regional data, yen strength,
and the NZ rate decision will lead event risk in Asia unless President-elect
Trump announces fresh policies.
    As the New Zealand economy struggles, 27 of 30 economists polled expect the
Reserve Bank of New Zealand to cut rates by 50 basis points to 4.25%, but the
RBNZ does like to surprise markets.
    Dow +0.28%, S&P +0.57%, and Nasdaq +0.66% as markets digested Trump's tariff
proposals and the divided Fed minutes. Treasury yields firmed on Trump's tariff
threats; 2yr -1bp at 4.248%, 10yr +3bps to 4.295%, and 30yr +2bps to 4.466% on
TradeWeb.
    Oil eased, Brent and WTI off 0.45%, capped by the Israel-Lebanon ceasefire. 
U.S. copper -1.05% as Trump's China tariffs weighed. Gold +0.3%, capped by the
Israel-Lebanon ceasefire but supported by Trump tariffs and Ukraine uncertainty.
    The U.S. dollar <=USD> closed unchanged after a choppy session dominated by
yen strength. USD/JPY fell 0.7% on Bank of Japan rate hike hopes after resilient
corporate service inflation, and Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba calling on
businesses for big wage rises next year; EUR/JPY -0.75%, GBP/JPY -0.7%, AUD/JPY
-1.15%. 
    EUR -0.1%, GBP steady, USD/CNH +0.15%, NZD -0.2% and USD/CAD +0.5% on the
Trump tariff news.

June 7 (Reuters) - The FX volatility on which options thrive is an
unknown yet key part of their premium, so dealers use implied volatility as a
stand in. A perfectly priced option will see realised volatility match implied
volatility, but changes in implied volatility can also be a bellwether for
realised volatility expectations over key events like Friday's U.S. nonfarm
payrolls data. 
    Overnight options have the shortest time to expiry - the next working day at
10 a.m. in New York (3 p.m. in London). Any additional implied volatility when
that expiry includes a key event will indicate additional realised volatility
expectations relating to that event and is easier to comprehend when converted
to premium/break even in terms of USD pips.  
    The initial implied volatility increase after including Friday's U.S.
nonfarm payrolls data was relatively tame by comparison to past NFP releases and
current break-evens for simple vanilla straddles reinforce that outlook on
Friday. 
    Using current implied volatility levels - the premium/break-even for
overnight EUR/USD implied volatility is around 40 USD pips from 32 pips prior in
either direction. The premium/break-even for overnight expiry AUD/USD is around
39 USD pips from 30 USD pips in either direction and overnight USD/JPY
premium/break-even is 98 JPY pips from 80 JPY pips in either direction. However,
all shorter dated JPY related options have seen demand and premium gains on
Friday amid renewed JPY gains, possibly relating to BoJ action next Friday.

* 
      Reuters reports China considering a weaker yuan on trade
threats
    

        * 
      Depreciation highlights broader FX implications of
tariffs,
economist says
    

        * 
      Yuan slips, Aussie dollar hits 1-yr low
    

  
    By Tom Westbrook and Alun John
       SINGAPORE/LONDON, Dec 11 (Reuters) - High-level
discussions in China about allowing its currency to weaken next
year underscore the risk for investors and companies that big
foreign exchange moves are coming as U.S. tariffs shift global
trade and money flows, analysts said.
    Reuters reported on Wednesday that China was considering
letting the yuan fall to weather what is likely to be a sharp
hike in tariffs, citing people familiar with the matter. The
yuan immediately dipped against the dollar, along with
currencies across Asia which are highly sensitive to Chinese
demand. [FRX/]
    While a weaker yuan had been widely expected, with pressure
on the exchange rate since the election of Donald Trump as U.S.
president, framing it as a policy shift may herald the start of
a new round of global tariffs, trade tensions and currency
intervention.
    "Currency adjustments are on the table as a tool to be used
to mitigate the effects of tariffs. I think that is clear," said
Fred Neumann, chief Asia economist at HSBC in Hong Kong.
    "Taking the currency weaker might be a signal by China to
the rest of the world that there are exchange rate implications
of imposing tariffs." 
    A cheaper exchange rate helps exporters by making their
prices more competitive internationally.
        The yuan <CNY=CFXS> dipped about 0.3% and as far as
7.2803 to the dollar after the Reuters report. The Australian
dollar <AUD=D3>, which is sensitive to moves in the yuan given
its hefty commodity exports, touched a one-year low.
    Trump has said he plans to impose a 10% universal tariff on
imports to the U.S. and a 60% tariff on Chinese goods.
    Financial markets have been bracing for more volatility from
his inauguration on Jan. 20, but have been unsure how seriously
to take his threats.   
    Reuters spoke to three people who have knowledge of the
discussions about letting the yuan weaken, one of whom said the
central bank had considered a fall to about 7.5 to the dollar -
roughly a 3.5% depreciation from current levels around 7.25.
    Still, that is at the weaker end of investment bank
expectations, adding to a sense among investors that China is
determined to be better prepared for trade shocks this time
around.
    "If they need to revitalise the economy, and they tend to be
more interested on focusing on exports, there is quite a
compelling logic that they may allow the renminbi to soften,"
said Jane Foley, head of currency strategy at Rabobank.
    
    INTENSE, FAST
    A complicating factor for China is where any slide would
leave the yuan relative to non-dollar currencies, especially in
Asia where many neighbours such as Vietnam have grown as hubs
for finishing Chinese manufactured goods and avoiding U.S.
sanctions.
    Rong Ren Goh, a portfolio manager in the fixed income team
at Eastspring Investments, said he expects China will
orchestrate a controlled and gradual depreciation but "Asian
currencies, particularly those of export-driven economies, are
likely to adjust in tandem with the yuan on a trade-weighted
basis."
    China's exporters have been hoarding dollars with an eye on
a rate of 7.5 as a point to start selling, but they have also
been seeking ways to avoid taking currency risks altogether by
invoicing in yuan and other such workarounds - especially as the
yuan has gained this year on peers <.CFSCNYI>.
    "If China takes the currency aggressively lower, it raises
the risk of a tariff cascade," said HSBC's Neumann, if it
prompts other economies to put up their own levies to protect
their industrial base from extremely cheap Chinese imports.
    "It could lead to a backlash among other trading partners,
and that's not in the interest of China."
    To be sure, much of the risk lies in the speed or shock
value of any U.S. move, and some market participants don't
expect Trump will be in a rush to take direct action. 
    "There’s some voices in markets calling for a quick 10-20%
depreciation (in the yuan) to help offset tariffs," said ING's
Greater China economist Lynn Song.
    "We don’t expect an intentional and sharp depreciation like
this as it will be ineffective to counteract tariffs, given this
could easily be categorized by the U.S. as currency manipulation
and result in further tariff hikes."       
    Still, at recent analysts' briefings in Singapore, Trump's
trade policy was seen as a true wildcard and a weaker Chinese
currency was the consensus for analysts at Nomura and MUFG.
    "My view is that there will be FX flexibility that comes
through," said Craig Chan, head of global currency strategy at
Nomura, before Reuters' report on China's forex discussions.
    He recommended a few long dollar positions in Asia.
    "Long dollar/CNH is one. We have a target of 7.60 by the end
of May. It could be intense, could be fast," he said. "That
would clearly be the risk to dollar/China - moving higher,
faster."
    And at MUFG, a forecast for a drop to 7.5 per dollar was
predicated on the assumption of an average 40% tariff on Chinese
goods.
    "A 60% tariff on China products would require a 10%-12% yuan
depreciation against the dollar (since September) to 7.8 or
beyond ... everything else being equal," MUFG analysts said.
        During Trump's first term as president, the yuan
weakened more than 12% against the dollar during a series of
tit-for-tat tariff announcements between March 2018 and May
2020. 
  

 (Additional reporting by Summer Zhen in Hong Kong and Vidya
Ranganathan in Singapore; Writing by Tom Westbrook; Editing by
Kim Coghill)

Aug 7 (Reuters) - Signs of stability returned to markets on Tuesday on a
growing perception that fears of a U.S. recession were overblown. Investors in
Asia will be hoping that the cautiously optimistic mood will not be undone by a
late swoon on Wall Street or China's trade data on Wednesday.
    Stock futures are lower in Asia with shares of server maker Super Micro
Computer down 12.1% in extended trading as its profit forecasts were below
analysts estimates.
    Wall Street rallied as dip-buyers stepped in, but closed well off the
intra-day high. Treasury yields rose as traders reassessed the chances of
aggressive interest cuts by the Federal Reserve, the U.S. dollar clawed back
some ground after its recent sharp decline, and commodities were mixed.
    China's July trade details highlight Asia's moderately busy data calendar,
with robust exports data expected. A speech by Bank of Japan deputy governor
Uchida Shinichi will be watched as the recent market rout tests the central
bank's rate hike resolve.
    Dow +0.8%, S&P +1%, and Nasdaq +1% but futures down 0.7%. U.S. yields
climbed as markets stabilized; 2yr +11bps to 3.9920%, 10yr +12bps to 3.9010% and
30yr +12bps to 4.1910%.
    Oil prices were slightly higher on Middle East tensions, Brent +0.2% and WTI
+0.4%. U.S. copper +0.25% made a guarded recovery and gold -0.6% on the stronger
dollar.
    The U.S. dollar <=USD> gained 0.25%; EUR -0.2%, GBP -0.68%, CHF flat, JPY
-0.1%, CAD -0.27% CNH -0.3% but AUD +0.37% and NZD +0.2% and a further 0.3%
Wednesday on better-than-expected jobs data.

(Updates headline, first paragraph, adds new analyst comment)
    By Chibuike Oguh and Harry  Robertson
       NEW YORK/LONDON, Nov 12 (Reuters) - The U.S. dollar rose
to a four-month high against major peers on Tuesday, while
bitcoin pared recent gains from a record rally buoyed by tariff
expectations from the incoming Donald Trump administration.
    Bitcoin <BTC=> dropped from a new all-time peak of $89,982
and was last down 1.2% to $86,945. Trump has vowed to make the
United States "the crypto capital of the planet". 
    "It's still an extension of the post-election moves; the
economic calendar has been relatively light although it's
picking up later in the week but for now the market is focusing
on the implications of a second Trump term, particularly
policies that would be positive for the dollar such as potential
higher tariffs," said Vassili Serebriakov, an FX strategist at
UBS in New York.
        Higher tariffs are expected to push up prices, leaving
the Federal Reserve less scope to cut interest rates.
  
    The U.S. dollar index <=USD>, which measures the currency
against six peers rose 0.53% to 105.98, hitting its highest
level since early July.
    Trump's Republican Party will hold a slim majority in both
houses of Congress, allowing the president-elect to push his
agenda cutting taxes and regulation after he takes office in
January.
    "There's been a broad move in the dollar that started before
the election and it probably got an added boost because it looks
like we're moving to a red sweep scenario, which is broadly seen
as positive for the dollar," Serebriakov added.
    Trump has warned that the euro bloc will "pay a big price"
for not buying enough American exports, with cars a particular
target. He has threatened China with blanket 60% tariffs.
    Since his election last week, the euro has languished at a
seven-month trough and the yuan slumped to its lowest in more
than three months, with Europe and China both targets of
potential Trump tariffs.
    The euro is feeling additional pressure from political
uncertainty in Germany, the bloc's biggest economy. Germany is
set to hold fresh elections on Feb. 23, which will be eleven
weeks after the collapse of Chancellor Olaf Scholz's governing
coalition.
    The euro <EUR=EBS> sank to $1.06065 on Tuesday, the lowest
since mid-April, and was last down 0.41% at $1.061.
        
    Sterling <GBP=D3> dropped 0.61% to $1.2791 after data showed
regular UK wage growth slowed and unemployment rose, with the
pound also feeling the heat from the dollar's rally.
    Against the Japanese yen, the dollar rose 0.46% to 154.41
yen <JPY=EBS>. The Japanese currency dropped to a three-month
low of 154.715 per dollar last week.

Sept 25 (Reuters) - While financial market have responded positively to
China's much-delayed stimulus package, economists remain sceptical, pointing out
that even more support will be needed. Yet Beijing is probably not done.
    Chinese stocks and the yuan continued to surge Wednesday, after Tuesday's
unveiling of a wide swathe of economic stimulus measures. The offshore yuan
extended its rally past the 7.0000 watermark to reach a new 16-month high of
6.9952. The Shanghai composite stock index surged 2.4% while Hong Kong's Hang
Seng sprinted 2.3% higher.
    The People's Bank of China delivered on its promise to cut rates, starting
with a 30 basis-point easing of the one-year medium-term lending facility rate
to 2.00%, as signalled on Tuesday. The seven-day reverse repo rate, earmarked to
be trimmed by 20 bps to 1.50%, is likely next.
    Still on the cards is a planned 50 bps slashing of banks' reserve
requirement ratio, as well as a cut in the benchmark one-year and five-year loan
prime rates; the latter affects household mortgages. 
    And there could be more in store beyond the telegraphed monetary policy
easing moves. Tuesday's coordinated announcement of the economic boosters
suggests policymakers' sense of urgency has risen another notch or three.
     While Beijing has acted judiciously to lower lending costs, support
property markets, reduce mortgage burdens, and to juice the equity markets,
there are a couple of major issues to address before naysayers will relent. 
    First, consumer confidence, which might pick up if property prices finally
turn a corner, possibly via a knock-on effect from a sustained rally in
equities. Second, joblessness, particularly among the youth, needs to be
remedied. Beijing must leave no stone unturned if it wants to hit its 2024 GDP
target.

       SHANGHAI/BEIJING, June 11 (Reuters) - China's yuan hit a
near seven-month low against the U.S. dollar on Tuesday, as
investors returned from a long weekend break and caught up with
broad greenback strength in overseas markets.
    The losses did not extend as major state-owned banks quickly
stepped in to sell dollars for yuan in the onshore spot foreign
exchange market to stabilise the local currency, sources told
Reuters.
    Yuan's weakness was largely in line with other currencies,
as the dollar was supported by higher U.S. Treasury yields in
the aftermath of surprisingly robust domestic jobs data on
Friday, which sparked a dramatic paring of bets for Federal
Reserve's interest rate cuts this year. [FRX/]
    The firmer greenback sent the official yuan midpoint to the
weakest level in nearly five months. Prior to market opening,
the People's Bank of China set the midpoint rate <CNY=PBOC> at
7.1135 per dollar, 29 pips weaker than the previous fix of
7.1106, and was the softest since Jan. 19.
    The spot yuan is allowed to trade in a 2% range on either
side of the daily official midpoint fixing. The guidance on
Tuesday capped the yuan's downside limit at 7.2558 per dollar.
    The cut in the official midpoint fixing has opened the door
for some weakness in spot prices, said a trader at a Chinese
bank.
    In the spot market, the onshore yuan <CNY=CFXS> opened at
7.2502 per dollar and weakened to a low of 7.2531 in early
trades, the weakest level since Nov. 16, 2023. It last traded at
7.2529 by midday.
    "Before the Fed starts cutting rates, the yuan exchange rate
may maintain the trend of depreciation against the U.S. dollar
and appreciation against a basket of currencies," analysts at
China International Capital Corporation said in a note. 
    They expect the yuan to maintain relatively low volatilities
in the second half of the year against the backdrop of Beijing's
policy stance towards a stable currency.
    The yuan's trade-weighted CFETS index <.CFSCNYI>, a gauge
that measures the yuan's value against its major trading
partners, stood at 99.97, its highest level since May 14,
according to Reuters calculation based on official data. 
    The CFETS index has gained 2.6% year-to-date, when the spot
yuan lost 2.1% to the greenback.
    Separately, traders said they would pay close attention to
China's May credit lending data this week to gauge the health of
the broad economy.
    A Reuters poll suggested that China's new yuan loans likely
rebounded in May from April, as the central bank told lenders to
quicken bank lending to support the economy.
    The offshore yuan <CNH=D3> followed the softening trend to
trade at 7.2669 per dollar as of midday, compared with the
previous close of 7.2656.

 (Reporting by Shanghai and Beijing Newsroom; Editing by Sonali
Paul and Rashmi Aich)

USD/CNH Implied Volatility Reaches Record High Amid U.S. ElectionNov 05, 2024

The short-term implied volatility for the Chinese Yuan has continued its upward trend, hitting a historic high during the U.S. election period. On Tuesday, the overnight implied volatility for USD/CNH soared to 30.16%, more than triple Monday's close of approximately 8.5%. This marks the highest level since data tracking began in 2011, surpassing the peaks from the 2016 and 2020 U.S. election cycles.

Meanwhile, the overnight volatility for EUR/USD is moving towards its biggest single-day increase since the global financial crisis of 2008-09. The one-week implied volatility for USD/CNH is currently at 15.5%, rising for the eighth consecutive day to reach a new historical peak. In addition, the one-month offshore Yuan implied volatility saw a slight increase to 8.91%, up from 8.82% on Monday.

March 22 (Reuters) - AUD/USD fell below the 200-DMA and daily cloud base
Friday as gains remained elusive even as U.S. yields softened, reinforcing
concerns that a much deeper drop is possible.
    Emerging market currencies, especially those in Asia, are under bearish
pressure against the U.S. dollar.
    Japan's rally toward a 32-year high has helped put EM and Asia currencies on
defense.
    That weakness was evident as USD/CNH <CNH=D3> rallied above the 200-DMA and
struck a 4-month high on possible further easing from the PBOC while India's
rupee <INR=D3> fell to an all-time low against the U.S. dollar.
    Commodities added to concern for AUD/USD longs. Gold <XAU=> traded lower
over the past two sessions after it recently struck an all-time high while
iron-ore <DCIOc2> remains sharply lower on a year-to-date basis.
    Technicals signals reinforce worries for AUD/USD longs.
    The pair traded below a slew of daily moving averages and the daily cloud
base and daily RSI implies downward momentum is in place. A monthly gravestone
doji candle is nearly formed for March.
    AUD/USD longs hold out hope that U.S. data can turn the tide in their favor.
    February PCE March 29 and March ISM non-manufacturing April 3 may throw
longs a life line if pricing indicates inflation is not running hot, which could
give the Fed reason to take a more dovish lean.

July 15 (Reuters) - U.S. June producer prices increased slightly more
than expected on Friday, but not enough to dent the rate cut optimism, while
consumer sentiment slipped. Wall Street climbed, short-end Treasury yields
eased, the USD fell and commodities closed mixed.
    In weekend news, Donald Trump survived an assassination attempt and headed
to the Republican convention. China's central bank-backed Financial News sent
another warning to buyers of government bonds. 
    A modest positive lead for Asian markets, with EM ETFs up 0.4%, while Japan
is on holiday. A raft of Chinese data led by GDP, June industrial output, and
retail sales, plus Indian wholesale prices will keep the focus on domestic
markets ahead of a busy week.
    The PBOC is expected to keep the interest rate on the one-year medium-term
lending facility loan rate unchanged at 2.50%. Traders will also keep an eye on
any news from the start of China's Third Plenum.
    Wall Street closed higher with the S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average
hitting intraday record highs on Federal Reserve rate cut hopes, Dow +0.62%, S&P
+0.55%, and Nasdaq +0.63%. The inverted Treasury curve flattened, 2yr -4bps to
4.460%, 10yr -1bp to 4.187% and 30yr steady at 4.401% on rate cut hopes.
    Oil slipped after soft consumer sentiment undermined U.S. demand hopes,
Brent -0.45% and WTI -0.5%. U.S. copper +1.7% on bargain-hunting and the softer
USD. Gold -0.15%, capped by profit-taking. 
    The U.S. dollar <=USD> fell 0.4% on Fed rate cut expectations. EUR +0.35%,
GBP +0.6% as hopes of political stability attract investment, USD/JPY -0.65%
amid intervention rumours, USD/CNH +0.05%, AUD +0.35%, NZD +0.4% and USD/CAD
flat as benchmark yields slipped.

(Updates at midday)
       SINGAPORE, Oct 8 (Reuters) - China's yuan fell to its
lowest level in nearly three weeks as
mainland markets opened on Tuesday after a week-long break,
weakened by the U.S. dollar's broad strength as frenzied buying
over recently unveiled stimulus plans propelled stocks higher.
    By 0334 GMT, the onshore yuan <CNY=CFXS> was 0.79% lower at
7.0666 to the dollar after trading in a range of 7.0488 to
7.0846. It had closed at 7.0175 per dollar before the holiday.
    The intraday low matched a level last seen on Sept. 19.
    China's offshore yuan <CNH=D3> was last at 7.0664 per dollar
around the midday.
    "Yuan has weakened because markets went into the holidays
short dollar-CNH and the stronger dollar led by Federal Reserve
repricing took some of these weak positions out," said Rong Ren
Goh, a portfolio manager in the fixed-income team at Eastspring
Investments.
    The dollar <=USD> has rallied to seven-week highs against
major currencies after a strong jobs report on Friday slashed
bets for large Fed rate cuts and escalating tensions in the
Middle East dented risk sentiment. The dollar is at multi-week
highs against the euro, sterling and the yen. [FRX/]
    Chinese shares soared to two-year highs on Tuesday following
the holiday, adding to a blistering rally seen before the break
as investors bet stimulus plans would support the economy. Hong
Kong shares though pulled back some recent gains built off of
the stimulus excitement.
    "RMB weakness, geopolitical tension and derivative
exuberance pose risks to the current rally," Jason Lui, head of
APAC equity and derivative strategy at BNP Paribas, said in a
note.
    He said the stronger dollar gave Chinese companies a chance
to sell their accumulated dollar assets, but added that the
broader dollar rally and yuan volatility may prompt some
uncertainty for equity investors.
    The chairman of the country's economic planner, the National
Development and Reform Commission, Zheng Shanjie said on Tuesday
that China was "fully confident" of achieving its full-year
economic and social development targets, adding some of 2025's
budget will be issued this year to support projects.
    China's bond market also saw some volatility, with 30-year
treasury yields <CN30YT=RR> jumping 8 basis points before
pulling back to a rise of about 2 basis points around midday.
    Prior to market opening, the People's Bank of China (PBOC)
set the midpoint rate <CNY=PBOC>, around which the yuan is
allowed to trade in a 2% band, at 7.0709 per dollar, its weakest
since Sept. 19, and 85 pips firmer than a Reuters' estimate
<CNY=RTRS> of 7.0709.
    The fixing was down 0.9% from the previous fix, the biggest
drop in percentage terms since May 2022.

CNH: Tolerance For Yuan Weakness In Focus Following Sharp Losses On FridayCNH: Tolerance For Yuan Weakness In Focus Following Sharp Losses On Friday

Friday highs in USD/CNH came close to 7.2800, before the pair closed around
7.2760 in NY. This was a CNH loss of 0.75%. Onshore spot finished up at 7.2292,
a loss of 0.41%, after USD/CNY finally broke above resistance at 7.2000 early
in Friday trade. The CNY NEER (J.P. Morgan index) fell 0.16% to 124.50.

* Technically, for USD/CNH, the break higher ends a period of sideways trading
  and confirms the resumption of the uptrend that started in Dec 2023. Our
  technical analyst believes that there is scope for a climb towards CNH7.3020,
  the 76.4% retracement of the Sep 8-Dec 29 bear leg.
* Focus is also likely to rest on the USD/CNY fixing, which pushed above 7.1000
  on Friday. A further rise in today's fix would likely be seen as a green
  light for further yuan losses. The other focus point will be state bank
  action, which was reportedly absent in early Friday trade (from a USD selling
  stand point), although reportedly came in later. The market will be looking
  to assess how much yuan weakness the authorities will tolerate.
* China Premier Li Qiang downplayed weaker economic risks during a speech at
  the China Development Forum yesterday and noted policy space remains ample
  (see this link: https://blinks.bloomberg.com/news/stories/SAQA01T0AFB4).
  Focus was also on potentially more supportive property policies following a
  State Council meeting late last week (see this link:
  https://blinks.bloomberg.com/news/stories/SAS8DCT0G1KW).
* Equity sentiment was a negative with the Golden Dragon index losing 1.8% in
  US trade on Friday. This followed onshore losses of around 1% for the CSI 300
  and Shanghai Composite Index in local onshore trade. Northbound stock connect
  flows were negative as well on Friday.
* The local data calendar is empty today.

taking Treasury yields higher, the focus on Monday swung to the escalating
Middle East conflict, and the approach of Hurricane Milton to the Florida coast.
    Wall Street fell, Treasury yields and oil climbed, metals slipped and the
U.S. dollar consolidated last week's gains. 
    A negative offshore lead, though EM ETFs rose 0.83%. Japanese current
account and trade figures lead the low-key data schedule, while the Reserve Bank
of Australia will release its September policy meeting minutes and RBA Deputy
Governor Andrew Hauser speaks at an event in Sydney. 
    The focus will be on the return of China after Golden Week, as officials
brief markets on implementing policies to promote economic growth.

 Yuan correlation with stocks isn't a two-way street 
 Global investors are keenly watching Chinese stocks for their impact on the yuan. Rallies on
the Shanghai Composite Index have lifted the currency, though mostly via a psychological effect,
since overseas equity investors remain leery of stocks. This correlation may, however, be
one-directional. USD/CNH downside could depend on whether the Shanghai stock rally sustains.
Conversely, upside appears limited, even if the SSEC sputters. USD/CNH has trended lower the
past week, coinciding with the SSEC rebounding as much as 14.2% from the Feb 5 low. The index
broke above the 3,000 points psychological barrier early Friday but is now flailing around that
watermark. A daily closing above 2,979 would clear its Ichimoku cloud resistance zone, paving a
way higher. That could restart the USD/CNH descent, which has stalled after bouncing off its own
cloud barrier at 7.1990. A Friday close below 7.1954, the entrance of the daily Bollinger
downtrend channel, would put it back on track. While officials accelerate efforts to support
stocks after a leadership change at the securities regulator, Chinese FX authorities continue to
put up a resolute defence of the currency via direct market intervention as well as through the
stubbornly stable USD/CNY fixing. This implies the yuan will only be allowed to react positively
to Chinese stock movements.

March 8 (Reuters) - FX option implied volatility rose from 2-year lows
this week, with a mild preference to own USD put over call strikes and the
biggest gains posted in JPY related pairings amid increased expectations of BoJ
policy action on March 19. 
    The NFP data wasn't strong enough to significantly impact a U.S. dollar that
was already ailing in the wake of Fed chair Powell's dovish rhetoric mid-week.
Mild profit-taking in shorter dated implied volatility should prove limited
ahead of Tuesday's U.S. CPI risk. 
    Benchmark 1-month expiry USD/JPY implied volatility is up almost 2.0 to the
mid 9's this week, while 1-month 25 delta risk reversal has seen its JPY call
over put premium reach highs not seen since late July, around 2.0.  
    EUR/USD 1-month expiry implied volatility traded 5.8 from a 5.6 base this
week, but overall price action is not yet warning about a sustained break above
1.1000. Risk reversals are still hanging on to a small downside strike premium. 
    GBP/USD 1-month implied volatility met demand on dips to 6.0 as its 1-month
expiry risk reversal posts its lowest downside over topside strike implied
volatility premium since mid 2020.  
    Benchmark 1-month expiry AUD/USD implied volatility was given a boost from
8.0 to 8.6 beside the 150pts spot rally to the mid 0.66's, but profit taking
then ensued. 1-month risk reversals trade a long term low for USD calls over
puts amid the broader USD weakness and improved risk sentiment.

Cici Cao

Hong Kong stocks crashed through the 20,000 mark to a month's low as the yuan
dropped to a three-month low against the US dollar over US President-elect
Donald Trump's tariff threat.

FWD Group chairman and former secretary for financial services and the
treasury, Frederick Ma Si-Hang, said many companies are prepared to relocate
their supply chains to regions outside China to avoid the tariffs expected to
be in excess of 60 percent.

Mainland stocks also dropped as the yuan weakened against the US dollar.
Sino-US tensions are expected to intensify during Trump's second term.

Hang Seng Index extended the loss yesterday, closing at 19,846 points, above
the 19,129 level on September 25 when China announced its biggest stimulus
package since the pandemic to pull the economy out of a deflationary threat.
Three major indexes of A shares all declined in afternoon trading, dragged
down by financial-related stocks. The Shanghai SSE Composite Index, for
example, shed 1.39 percent.

The offshore yuan once weakened to 7.25054 per dollar, hitting a three-month
low.

In Hong Kong, medical stocks leaped on China's announcement of improvement
plans for an advance payment system for basic medical insurance funds.

WuXi AppTec (2359) gained 1.42 percent, WuXi XDC Cayman (2268) jumped 7.46
percent and Sinopharm Group (1099) rose 2.17 percent.

AIA Group (1299) announced that the National Financial Regulatory
Administration Chongqing Bureau has permitted AIA China to establish a new
branch in the Chongqing Municipality, following the opening of branches in
Anhui Province and Shandong Province.

Its share price declined 2.56 percent to HK$59 yesterday.

Meanwhile, bitcoin roared to an all-time high of US$89,637 (HK$699,168) in
anticipation that Trump's second term will bring equities-boosting tax cuts
and deregulations.

In other news, FWD's Ma said Hong Kong's status as a container port and
ranking in the cultural industry had been taken over by competitors in the
past 20 years, with its technological development also falling behind.

Speaking at a forum organized by Macau-based Delta Asia Financial Group, Ma
urged the Hong Kong government to actively promote the initiatives mentioned
in the policy address, saying he was pessimistic about China-US relations but
expressing belief that it is still possible for the two economies to
cooperate.

Aug 19 (Reuters) - Resilient U.S. consumer sentiment and steady
inflation expectations resulted in firmer U.S. stocks, softer Treasury yields, a
lower U.S. dollar and oil prices, while metals closed mixed on Friday. 
    In weekend news San Francisco Federal Reserve President Mary Daly and
Chicago Fed President Austan Goolsbee expressed support for a September Fed rate
cut.
    A positive lead for Asian markets with EM ETFs up 1.16%. Japanese machinery
orders, Thai GDP, and Malaysian trade figures lead the regional data schedule,
which should keep the focus on domestic markets unless there is news.    
    Expectations into the Fed's Jackson Hole Economic Policy Symposium on Aug 
22-24 will likely lead sentiment this week.
    Dow +0.24%, S&P +0.19%, and Nasdaq +0.21% as fears of an economic slowdown
eased. Treasury yields slipped; 2yr -4bps to 4.066%, 10yr -3bps to 3.892% and
30yr -3bps to 4.151% on rate cut optimism.
    Oil fell on China demand fears, Brent -1.6%, WTI -1.9%. U.S. copper -0.05%,
capped by easing supply expectations, and gold +2.1% on Fed rate cut optimism.
    The safe-haven U.S. dollar <=USD> fell 0.6% on dovish Fed expectations and
hopes of a 'soft' economic landing, weakening against all the major currencies.
EUR +0.5%, GBP +0.7%, USD/JPY -1.15%, USD/CNH -0.3%, AUD +0.9%, NZD +0.15% and
USD/CAD -0.4%.
